title: Job Interview Mastery
description: Ace your next job interview in English. This course covers everything from preparation and first impressions to tackling tough questions and negotiating your offer.

lessons.title: Lesson 1: The 'Tell Me About Yourself' Opener

sentences.text: I'm a software developer with over five years of experience in the fintech industry.
My journey began at XYZ University, where I majored in computer science.
I'm passionate about building scalable solutions that solve real-world problems.
In my previous role, I was responsible for leading the back-end development team.

phrases: This role aligns with my career goals
I was drawn to this opportunity because...

lessons.title: Lesson 2: Answering Behavioral Questions (STAR Method)

sentences.text: A situation I faced was a tight project deadline with changing requirements.
My task was to reprioritize the features and manage the team's workload effectively.
The action I took was to implement daily stand-up meetings to improve communication.
As a result, we delivered the core product on time and received positive feedback.

phrases: Let me give you an example
What I learned from this was...
Tell me about a time when...

lessons.title: Lesson 3: Discussing Strengths and Weaknesses

sentences.text: One of my greatest strengths is my ability to adapt to new technologies quickly.
I pride myself on my strong problem-solving and analytical skills.
In the past, I sometimes took on too much work myself.
However, I've learned to delegate tasks effectively to improve team efficiency.

phrases: I've taken steps to address this
Turning a weakness into a strength

lessons.title: Lesson 4: Asking Insightful Questions

sentences.text: Can you describe the day-to-day responsibilities of this role?
What does success look like in this position in the first ninety days?
What are the biggest challenges the team is currently facing?
How would you describe the company culture and work environment?

phrases: I have a few questions for you
Could you tell me more about...
What are the opportunities for growth?
Can you describe the team dynamic?
What's the next step in the process?

lessons.title: Lesson 5: Following Up and Negotiating

sentences.text: Thank you for taking the time to speak with me today.
I am very excited about the possibility of joining your team.
Based on my experience and the market rate, I was expecting a salary in this range.
Is there any flexibility in the compensation package you've offered?

phrases: I look forward to hearing from you
I'd like to discuss the salary

title: Tech Industry Communication
description: Navigate the fast-paced tech world. Learn to lead stand-ups, conduct code reviews, explain technical concepts to non-technical stakeholders, and manage incidents.

lessons.title: Lesson 1: Running an Effective Stand-up

sentences.text: Yesterday, I pushed the final commits for the user authentication service.
Today, I'll be focusing on writing the integration tests for the new API endpoint.
I'm currently blocked by a dependency issue in the shared library.
Does anyone have context on the recent changes to the deployment pipeline?

phrases: The pull request is ready for review

lessons.title: Lesson 2: Explaining Technical Trade-offs

sentences.text: We can build a quick solution now, but it will create significant technical debt.
Opting for a microservices architecture will improve scalability but increase operational complexity.
The trade-off here is between development speed and long-term maintainability.
To the product team, this means a slower initial launch but faster feature delivery later.

phrases: Let's weigh the pros and cons

lessons.title: Lesson 3: Conducting a Code Review

sentences.text: Overall, the logic looks solid, but I have a few minor suggestions.
Could we extract this logic into a separate helper function to improve reusability?
This variable name is a bit ambiguous; could we make it more descriptive?
Please add a comment here explaining why this unconventional approach was necessary.

phrases: This could be a potential edge case
Can you add a unit test for this?

sentences.text: The incident began at 14:30 UTC and was resolved by 15:15 UTC.
The root cause was identified as a misconfiguration in the load balancer.
The immediate action was to roll back the recent deployment.
Our primary action item is to add automated checks to prevent this in the future.

title: University Seminar Success
description: Master the art of academic discourse. Learn to confidently state your thesis, support claims with evidence, challenge arguments respectfully, and lead engaging discussions.

lessons.title: Lesson 1: Stating Your Position

sentences.text: In my view, the author's primary argument is fundamentally flawed.
The central thesis of my presentation is that economic factors were the main catalyst.
I would argue that we need to reconsider the traditional interpretation of this event.
My position is that the social implications far outweigh the political ones.

phrases: From my reading of the text...
The main point I want to make is...
I'd like to start by asserting...

sentences.text: To support this point, I would like to cite the study by Johnson from 2021.
As evidence, consider the statistical data presented on page forty-five.
This is further substantiated by the primary source documents we reviewed last week.
A compelling example of this can be found in the second chapter.

lessons.title: Lesson 3: Agreeing and Disagreeing Respectfully

sentences.text: I agree with Sarah's point, and I'd like to add that...
That's a valid perspective, however, have you considered the alternative?
I see your point, but I'm not entirely convinced that it applies here.
I respectfully disagree with that interpretation for a couple of reasons.

phrases: To build on what you said...
I see what you mean, but...
I'm afraid I have to disagree
That's one way of looking at it, however...

sentences.text: Could you elaborate on what you mean by 'cultural hegemony'?
I'm not sure I follow your line of reasoning, could you explain it again?
If I understand correctly, you are arguing that the conclusion is invalid?
What specific evidence are you basing that assertion on?

title: The Independent Traveler
description: Go beyond the basics. Learn to handle common travel problems like a pro, from missed flights and lost luggage to navigating local healthcare and changing your plans on the fly.

lessons.title: Lesson 1: At the Airport - When Things Go Wrong

sentences.text: I seem to have missed my connecting flight, what are my options?
My luggage did not arrive on the carousel, where do I file a report?
My flight has been cancelled, could you please rebook me on the next available one?
I'm afraid my passport has been stolen, I need to contact my embassy.

phrases: I need to make a call

lessons.title: Lesson 2: Accommodation Issues

sentences.text: The room is not what I expected from the pictures online.
The air conditioning in my room doesn't seem to be working.
I seem to have been overcharged for my stay, can we review the bill?
I need to check out late, is that possible and is there a fee?

phrases: I'd like to speak to the manager
Can you move me to another room?

lessons.title: Lesson 3: Health and Safety

sentences.text: Can you recommend a doctor or a clinic that is open now?
I'm not feeling well, I think I have food poisoning.
Where is the nearest pharmacy that is open twenty-four hours?
I need to report a theft to the local police.

phrases: Can you call a taxi for me?

lessons.title: Lesson 4: Transportation and Navigation

sentences.text: The taxi meter isn't running, could you please turn it on?
I think this bus is going in the wrong direction.
I'd like to buy a train ticket to Berlin for tomorrow morning.
My rental car has a flat tire, can you send assistance?

phrases: Can you show me on the map?

title: English for Creatives: Pitching Your Art
description: Learn the language to articulate your artistic vision. This course covers writing artist statements, pitching projects to galleries, discussing your influences, and networking at events.

lessons.title: Lesson 1: The Artist Statement

sentences.text: My work explores the complex relationship between identity and memory.
Through my practice, I seek to challenge conventional notions of beauty.
I primarily work with mixed media, incorporating found objects into my paintings.
This series is a visual commentary on the effects of rapid urbanization.

phrases: I'm interested in the theme of...

lessons.title: Lesson 2: Pitching a Project or Exhibition

sentences.text: I am proposing a solo exhibition of my latest body of work.
The exhibition would feature ten large-scale oil paintings and three installations.
The central theme of the proposed show is 'Digital Traces'.
I believe this collection would resonate strongly with your gallery's audience.

phrases: I'd like to submit a proposal
The concept behind the project is...

lessons.title: Lesson 3: Discussing Your Work with a Collector

sentences.text: The inspiration for this piece came from a trip to the Scottish Highlands.
The technique I used involves applying multiple layers of translucent glaze.
This particular work took about three months to complete from start to finish.
I was trying to capture a feeling of nostalgia and fleeting time.

phrases: What I'm trying to convey is...

lessons.title: Lesson 4: Networking at an Art Fair or Opening

sentences.text: Your work is incredibly powerful, I was particularly struck by the use of color.
I'm a painter based in Brooklyn, it's a pleasure to meet you.
What are your thoughts on the curation of this exhibition?
It was great connecting with you, let's stay in touch.

phrases: I'm a big fan of your work
What are you working on now?
Can I give you my card?

title: Everyday English: The Absolute Basics
description: The perfect starting point. This course covers the most essential words and phrases you need for simple, everyday interactions, from 'hello' to 'how are you?'

sentences.text: Hello, my name is Maria.
Good morning, it is a nice day.
It was nice to meet you.
Goodbye, have a great evening!
How are you today?
I am fine, thank you.
What is your name?
Where are you from?
Today is Monday.
I have two brothers and one sister.
The meeting is at ten o'clock.
Excuse me, what time is it?
Could you help me, please?
Thank you so much for your help.
Excuse me, I have a question.
I'm sorry, I don't understand.

title: Shopping & Services for Beginners
description: Feel confident when you shop and use services. Learn essential vocabulary for the grocery store, clothes shopping, and ordering at a cafe.

sentences.text: Where can I find the milk?
How much are these apples?
I would like two kilos of potatoes, please.
Do you accept credit cards?
I'm looking for a blue t-shirt.
Do you have this in a medium size?
Where is the fitting room?
This is too expensive for me.
Can I have a coffee, please?
I would like a slice of chocolate cake.
Is that for here or to go?
Could we have the bill, please?
I would like to mail this letter.
How much is a stamp for a postcard to Japan?
I need to send this package, please.
When will it arrive?

title: Getting Around Town
description: Navigate your city with ease. Learn how to ask for and understand directions, take a taxi, and use public transportation like buses and trains.

sentences.text: Excuse me, where is the nearest bank?
How can I get to the train station?
Is the museum far from here?
Sorry to bother you, I am lost.
Go straight ahead for two blocks.
Turn left at the next corner.
The pharmacy is on your right.
It's across the street from the park.
Please take me to this address.
How much will it be to the airport?
Could you stop here, please?
How long will the ride take?
One ticket to the city center, please.
Which bus goes to the university?
Does this train stop at Grand Central?
What is the next stop?

title: Making Friends: First Conversations
description: Learn how to start conversations and make new friends. This course covers simple introductions, talking about your life, and finding common interests.

sentences.text: Hi, I'm Alex. It's nice to meet you.
I'm from Brazil, but I live in London now.
This is my friend, Sofia.
How do you two know each other?

lessons.title: Lesson 2: Talking About Your Job and Studies

sentences.text: I am a student at the local university.
I work as a graphic designer.
What do you do for a living?
I really enjoy my job.

lessons.title: Lesson 3: Talking About Hobbies and Interests

sentences.text: In my free time, I like to read books.
What kind of music do you listen to?
I love watching movies on the weekend.
Do you play any sports?
Would you like to get a coffee sometime?
Are you free on Saturday afternoon?
That sounds great, I'd love to.
Sorry, I'm busy then, maybe another time?

title: Handling Everyday Problems
description: Life isn't always perfect. Learn the essential English to handle common problems confidently, from returning a broken product to complaining about bad service.

lessons.title: Lesson 1: Returning a Faulty Product

sentences.text: I bought this coffee machine here last week, and it's stopped working.
I'd like to return this item because it's the wrong size.
I still have the receipt and all the original packaging.
Could I get a full refund instead of store credit?

phrases: I'd like to make a return

lessons.title: Lesson 2: Complaining at a Restaurant

sentences.text: Excuse me, I believe there is a mistake on our bill.
I'm afraid my steak is undercooked, I asked for it well-done.
We have been waiting for our food for over forty-five minutes.
This isn't what I ordered, I think there has been a mix-up.

phrases: This is not what I ordered
Could I speak to the manager?

sentences.text: Hi, I'm calling because my internet connection has been down all day.
I have already tried restarting my router, but it didn't help.
Can you tell me if there is a service outage in my area?
I need to schedule a technician to come and look at it.
My hotel room key card doesn't seem to be working.
I think I left my sunglasses in the taxi, is there a lost and found?
I need to change my flight reservation for tomorrow.
There appears to be an unexpected charge on my hotel bill.

title: English for Health and Wellness
description: Take control of your health. Learn to clearly describe symptoms to a doctor, discuss fitness goals at a gym, and talk about nutrition and mental well-being.

lessons.title: Lesson 1: The Detailed Doctor's Visit

sentences.text: The pain is a dull ache that gets worse at night.
I have been feeling dizzy and I have no appetite.
I am allergic to penicillin, so I cannot take that.
What are the side effects of this medication?

phrases: A sharp pain or a dull ache

sentences.text: I'd like to sign up for a monthly gym membership.
Can you show me how to use the leg press machine?
What kind of fitness classes do you offer in the evenings?
My main goal is to improve my cardiovascular fitness.

lessons.title: Lesson 3: Talking About Diet and Nutrition

sentences.text: I am trying to cut down on processed foods.
Does this meal contain any nuts? I have a serious allergy.
I'm looking for high-protein, vegetarian meal options.
How many calories are in this serving?
I have been feeling very stressed and anxious lately.
It's important to find a good work-life balance.
I find that meditation helps me to clear my mind.
I think I might be experiencing burnout from my job.

title: Your Home: Renting and Living
description: Master the English needed for your home life. Learn how to find an apartment, communicate with landlords, set up utilities, and interact with neighbors.

sentences.text: I'm calling about the two-bedroom apartment listed online.
Is it possible to schedule a viewing sometime this week?
Are any utilities, like water or gas, included in the rent?
What is the policy on having pets in the apartment?
I'm writing to report that the faucet in the kitchen is leaking.
The heater in my bedroom is not working, and the room is very cold.
Could you please let me know when a repair person can come?
I would like to give my thirty-day notice to vacate the apartment.
I would like to set up a new internet account for my address.
What are the different internet speed packages that you offer?
I need to schedule an installation appointment for next Tuesday.
Can you please help me understand my first electricity bill?
Hi, I just moved in next door, my name is Chris.
I'm sorry to bother you, but would you mind turning the music down a bit?
We are having a few friends over on Saturday, we'll try to keep the noise down.
A package for you was delivered to my apartment by mistake.

title: Digital Life & Social Media
description: Speak naturally about the digital world. Learn to discuss your favorite apps, troubleshoot simple tech problems, and understand common online language and etiquette.

lessons.title: Lesson 1: Talking About Apps and Websites

sentences.text: What's your favorite app for listening to podcasts?
I use that website all the time for booking flights.
You should download this app, it's really useful for learning languages.
The user interface on their new update is a little confusing.
Have you tried turning it off and on again?
My phone battery has been draining really fast today.
I can't connect to the Wi-Fi network, do you know the password?
I think I need to clear my cache, the website is loading slowly.
Did you see the photo I tagged you in on Instagram?
I'm going to post these vacation pictures on my feed later.
That video went viral on TikTok last week.
Just send me a direct message with your contact info.
